Generics

Generics allow you to write code in which you can use a placeholder â€“ variable names â€“ instead of actual type names, which will then be substitued with real types when you use that code later. This is a really powerful feature and is a great way to avoid code duplication.

Defining a Generic Class

To define a Generic Class you define a class and append

ğŸš variable type

for each generic argument the class shall take. This structure is called generic argument. variable is the name of the argument. type is a generic argument constraint and types provided for this argument must be compatible with that constraint.

In the class body you can reference to the generic type arguments by its name.

See this example for a â€œboxâ€ that can store objects.

ğŸ‡ ğŸ ğŸš T ğŸ”µ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° content T

  ğŸˆ âœ‚ï¸ =content T ğŸ‡
    ğŸ® content =content
  ğŸ‰

  ğŸ– ğŸ‰ â¡ï¸ T ğŸ‡
    ğŸ content
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‰

Subclassing a Generic Class

Naturally you can subclass a generic class. Like in any other circumstance you have to provide values for the superclassâ€™s generic arguments. For instance:

ğŸ‡ â˜‘ï¸ ğŸ ğŸš ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

If the subclass itself takes a generic argument this argument can be used as argument for the superclass:

ğŸ‡ ğŸŒŸ ğŸš A ğŸ”µ ğŸ ğŸš A ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

Compatibility

Generic classes with arguments are only compatible if they have exactly the same arguments. So ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡ is only compatible to ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡ but not to ğŸ¨ğŸšâšªï¸ as one might expect.

The following example will not compile and illustrates why this kind of type conversion is not allowed.

ğŸ¦ listOfStrings ğŸ¨ ğŸ”¤CuriosityğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤Doesnâ€™tğŸ”¤ ğŸ†

ğŸ° listOfSomethings ğŸ¨ğŸšâšªï¸
ğŸ® listOfSomethings listOfStrings
ğŸ‘´ Our list of strings is now suddenly a list of somethings
ğŸ‘´ (remember listOfSomethings points to the same list as listOfStrings)

ğŸ» listOfSomethings 13 ğŸ‘´ Add an integer

ğŸ”‚ string listOfStrings ğŸ‡
  ğŸ‘´ The program would crash as thereâ€™s an integer in our list of strings
  ğŸ˜€ string
ğŸ‰

Generic Methods and Intializers

Itâ€™s also possible to define a generic method, class method or intializer. A generic procedure is a method, class method or intializer that takes generic arguments which then can be used as argument types, as return types or as types in the method body.

A good example from the standard library is ğŸ¨â€™s ğŸ° method. It is defined like this:

ğŸ– ğŸ° ğŸšAâšªï¸ callback ğŸ‡Elementâ¡ï¸AğŸ‰ â¡ï¸ ğŸ¨ğŸšA ğŸ‡
  ğŸ‘´ ...
ğŸ‰

Therefore the complete method syntax is:

ğŸ– name [generic-arguments] [arguments] [return-type] ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰
generic-arguments âŸ¶ generic-argument | generic-argument generic-arguments
generic-argument âŸ¶ ğŸš variable type

As you can see above it takes one generic argument named A which is restricted to subtypes of âšªï¸, that is any type. Now, if you'd wish to call this method you can know provide the generic type arguments after the object or class on which on which you call the method:

ğŸ¦ list ğŸ¨ğŸ”¤aağŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤12345ğŸ”¤ğŸ†
ğŸ° list ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡ a ğŸ”¡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ”¡
  ğŸ ğŸªa ğŸ”¤!ğŸ”¤ğŸª
ğŸ‰

Emojicode is, however, actually capable of automatically inferring the generic arguments for you, so you could just write:

ğŸ° list ğŸ‡ a ğŸ”¡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ”¡
  ğŸ ğŸªa ğŸ”¤!ğŸ”¤ğŸª
ğŸ‰

and Emojicode will automatically provide ğŸ”¡ as generic argument for A.

Generic Protocols

Itâ€™s also possible to define generic protocols. Generic protocols work very similar to generic classes and the same compatibility rules apply.

A generic protocol which you might use is ğŸ”‚.

ğŸŠ ğŸ”‚ğŸšElementâšªï¸ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ– ğŸ¡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ¡ğŸšElement
ğŸ‰

It takes one generic argument Element which determines the generic argument for the iterator (ğŸ¡) the ğŸ¡ method must return.

A class conforming to this protocol must pass a generic argument, like the string class does for example:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ“´ ğŸ‡
  ğŸŠ ğŸ¡ğŸšğŸ”£

  ğŸ‘´ ...
ğŸ‰

ğŸ‹ ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
  ğŸŠ ğŸ”‚ğŸšğŸ”£

  ğŸ‘´ ...

  ğŸ– ğŸ¡ â¡ï¸ ğŸ“´ ğŸ‡
     ğŸ‘´ ...
  ğŸ‰
ğŸ‡

Runtime Typing (Casting)

Hint

This is a 0.x limitation. Enhancements in the future will possibly remove this limitation.

At the moment itâ€™s not possible to store the type information of instances of generic classes at runtime. Therefore casts to classes with specific generic arguments cannot be verified and are forbidden. You will be confronted with the following error message if you try that anyway:

Dynamic casts involving generic type arguments are not possible yet. Please specify the generic argument constraints of the class for compatibility with future versions.

When you perform a cast you must always specify the generic argument constraint for each argument. Example:

ğŸ° box âšªï¸

ğŸ”² box ğŸğŸšğŸ”¡

The above example will not compile. Instead you have to specify:

ğŸ° box âšªï¸

ğŸ”² box ğŸğŸšğŸ”µ
